docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women and those who might become pregnant should not eat shark, swordfish, king mackerel or tilefish, because they could contain enough mercury to hurt an unborn baby's developing brain, the government has warned. In issuing the warning on Friday, the Food and Drug Administration rejected calls to also put tuna on the list, saying the other fish contain far more mercury than tuna does.

headline.main: F.D.A. Warns Women Not to Eat Some Fish

docs.abstract: FDA warns pregnant women and those who might become pregnant not to eat shark, swordfish, king mackerel or tilefish because they could contain enough mercury to hurt an unborn baby's developing brain; rejects calls to put tuna on list (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists in Portland, Ore., report that they have inserted a foreign gene into a monkey egg, fertilized the egg and produced a baby monkey with the added gene in its cells. The scientists say they believe that this is the first time researchers have used techniques of genetic engineering to alter an unfertilized egg of a primate, intending that the change be passed on to future generations.

headline.main: Monkey Born With Genetically Engineered Cells

docs.abstract: Scientists say they inserted foreign gene into monkey egg, fertilized egg and produced baby monkey with added gene in its cells; say this may be first time researchers have used techniques of genetic engineering to alter unfertilized egg of primate, intending that change be passed on to future generations; gene, which came from jellyfish, causes cells to make protein that glows under fluorescent light; monkey's cells have gene, but they are not making protein, and it is too soon to tell whether monkey's sperm will contain added gene; Dr Gerald Schatten, who reported experiment in journal Science, calls this an incremental step; says ultimate goal is to create colonies of monkeys that have been genetically modified to develop human disease, to be used on study of new treatments for humans with that disease; Patricia Backlar, ethicist, says effort is likely to be controversial; photo; diagrams (M)
docs.snippet: Scientists in Portland, Ore., report that they have inserted a foreign gene into a monkey egg, fertilized the egg and produced a baby monkey with the added gene in its cells.     The scientists say they believe that this is the first time researchers...

docs.lead_paragraph: INSPIRED SLEEP By Robert Cohen Scribner. 398 pages. $25. Feel unhappy? Take a pill. The remedy is common to our culture, and to our doctors, and of course to the mental health insurers. Though not unknown, it is hardly as common to our history or to vast parts of the world (Rwanda, say, or East Timor) that we inhabit somewhat, as one inhabits a haunted house. When filtered through our own distracted prosperity, the agonies and deprivations of other societies register on us like ghosts.

headline.main: Love and Medication in an Age of Anxiety and Insomnia

docs.abstract: Richard Eder reviews book Inspired Sleep by Robert Cohen; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Manhattan obstetrician with a celebrity clientele was convicted yesterday of defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures, a case that was closely watched by doctors and their patients in the booming fertility industry. The doctor, Niels H. Lauersen, was convicted of something that many in his profession have quietly done for years: billing insurance companies for covered gynecological procedures to mask the uncovered fertility procedures he was performing.

headline.main: Doctor Convicted of Insurance Fraud in Fertility Procedures

docs.abstract: Dr Niels H Lauersen, Manhattan obstetrician with celebrity clientele, is convicted of defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures, case that was closely watched by doctors and their patients in booming fertility industry; many experts expect outcome to set template for future cases and perhaps even policy regarding fertility treatments, costly procedures that are rarely covered by health insurance policies, something women have challenged in courts; photo (M)

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and SHERRI DAY

docs.lead_paragraph: After an electrical problem froze elevators in two Midtown office towers, firefighters spent yesterday afternoon tearing down walls to rescue people from elevators and carrying elderly people down 50 flights of stairs on makeshift litters. The 22 elevators in 370 and 380 Lexington Avenue, which are across 41st Street from each other, stopped after an explosion in a nearby manhole about 1:45 p.m., the authorities said. Service was restored at 8:55 p.m., Con Edison said.

headline.main: Elevators Fail In Two Towers, Stranding 14 For an Hour

docs.abstract: Electrical problem freezes elevators in two Midtown Manhattan office towers stranding 14 for an hour; firefighters tear down walls to rescue people from elevators and carry elderly people down 50 flights of stairs on makeshift litters (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many 13-year-old boys, Xavier Valdez loved to play video games, particularly WrestleMania 2000 and a baseball game, Triple Play 2000. And, like many boys growing up in the Bronx, he was a big fan of the New York Yankees. Xavier's father, Raymon, bought him a Playstation 2 the day after Xavier underwent surgery for scoliosis in October at the Hospital for Special Surgery on the Upper East Side. Xavier had inexplicably fallen into a coma after the surgery, but his father was sure he would wake up soon and begin playing games again.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; The Kindness of Strangers Helps Ease a Family's Pain

docs.abstract: Family of 13-year-old Xavier Valdez describes how New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helped pay for boy's funeral; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: George W. Bush's cabinet may look like America, but on a host of important domestic policy issues it sure doesn't think like America. We are about to embark on a rough ride into the distant past. John Ashcroft, Mr. Bush's choice for attorney general, believes, for example, that if a 13-year-old girl were raped by her father and made pregnant, she should be required to carry that pregnancy to term. Most Americans do not feel that way.

headline.main: In America; Far, Far From the Center

docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says while Pres-elect George W Bush's cabinet may look like America, it does not think like majority of Americans on host of important domestic policy issues (M),
